player.seasonOutlook: Let's start with the positives: Schwarber walked more than ever last season (15.3 percent walk rate), trimmed his strikeout rate slightly and stayed healthy enough to rack up a career-high 510 plate appearances. Not surprisingly, he offered plenty of pop along the way (26 homers) and his defense improved from terrible to below average. As for the downside, he still didn't bring much to the table in terms of batting average, hitting .238 and carrying an XBA (.244) that doesn't offer much hope if his current batted-ball profile is his true baseline. The aforementioned defensive improvement probably isn't enough to spare him from late-inning exits in close games, and he seems unlikely to get more starts against left-handed pitching even though he improved against southpaws in limited chances (85 wRC+). Most likely, he will remain capped on the big side of a platoon in left field while offering 25-30 homer pop and a mediocre average.

Molina has now played 15 major-league seasons, and in his 15th in 2018, he managed his second-most home runs (20) and second-highest isolated power (.174). It was a testament to his extraordinary ability, driven in large part by his elite contact rate ? 88.9 percent for his career and 85.6 percent in 2018. Make no mistake, though: Molina is aging (albeit gracefully), as his .261 batting average was his lowest in 12 years, he has posted the two worst strikeout rates in any full year of his career in the past two seasons and his expected wOBA (per Statcast) has been trending in the wrong direction in the past two years despite his distinct shift toward driving the ball. So long as you regard him more as a top-10 than top-five catcher in fantasy, you'll be getting one of the most likely backstops to meet his draft-day price tag. Just be forewarned that there's not much profit potential.

A brilliant defender with excellent speed, Bader is too valuable an asset to the St. Louis Cardinals in center field for him to sit. That's good news, because he comes with limitations ? for example, against right-handed pitching last season, he batted just .251 with .127 isolated power and a 31.1 percent strikeout rate. And he doesn't generate much hard contact; his 30.8 percent rate per Statcast ranked in the bottom third in the majors. Consider Bader a role-dependent source of home runs and stolen bases, but little more than that. His is a valuable skill set in mixed Rotisserie leagues, but he's more of an NL-only option if using points-based scoring.

At first glance, LeMahieu's average and OBP tumbled to four-year lows (.276 AVG, .321 OBP), and he took a step back offensively. But a closer look reveals that his approach shifted, as he hit more fly balls than ever before (29.5 percent) en route to a career-high 15 homers. At age 30, it's possible that LeMahieu is trying to maximize the overall value of his skillset, parlaying his ability to maintain a low strikeout rate and spray the ball to all fields with an added willingness to pull the ball in the air to do damage when appropriate. That will play well at Yankee Stadium, his new home park as a result of him signing a two-year deal with New York. LeMahieu's elite defensive skills should help him earn at-bats with his new club, but given the Yankees' depth, he may open the season in some sort of utility role. Leaving Colorado often drives down the price of hitters, and there are some concerns about playing time, but LeMahieu might be a sneaky player in the midst of a mid-career power surge, available on the cheap this draft season.

Milwaukee might've been the ideal landing spot for a player of Grandal's skill set: So much of his game is centered upon power and Miller Park is one of the game's best venues for home runs. He has heightened his launch angle in each of the four years for which Statcast has data, has maintained a roughly 40 percent hard-contact rate and is the only catcher to have posted at least 450 plate appearances and .200 isolated power in each of the past three seasons. Considering the dearth of quality catchers, Grandal is a solid, undoubtedly top-10 option at the position, whether in a Rotisserie or points-based league.

Martinez is effectively a man without a position, as he's a poor defender at both first base and in right field, and the St. Louis Cardinals have other offensively oriented alternatives at both spots. That's why he was on the trade rumor mill all offseason, though as the season dawns, it appears that he'll get the majority of the at-bats in right field and the team will live with his shaky glove. Martinez made quite a bit more contact in 2018 (80.5 percent) than in 2017 (77.9 percent), posted a near-identical hard contact rate and tallied 590 plate appearances despite those defensive questions. Competition will be fiercer this time around with Paul Goldschmidt on board, but the lineup will also be deeper, which will help Martinez's counting numbers. He's worth a mid-round selection, and in the event he's dealt to an American League team that can use him at designated hitter, his value could receive a sizable boost.

A ruptured biceps tendon ended Cabrera's 2018 season after a hamstring injury had previously limited him to just 38 games. When he was on the field, it was easy to wonder if Cabrera was healthy, as his ground ball rate skyrocketed to a career-high 54.6 percent (up from 39.8 percent in 2017) and his home run output plummeted to just three long balls in 157 plate appearances. Cabrera still walked a lot (14.0 percent walk rate), but his .448 SLG was the second-lowest mark of his career, ahead of only the .399 mark he posted in 2017. Cabrera resumed hitting in December, and he's expected to be 100 percent healthy for the start of spring training. With consecutive injury-marred campaigns and his 36th birthday coming in April, it's fair to wonder if Father Time has caught up to Cabrera once and for all. If a bounce-back season in the power department happens, it might be accompanied by more frequent days off. Making things bleaker, the Tigers are in the early stages of a major rebuilding process which has left a very weak supporting cast around Cabrera.

It's really hard to be underappreciated at catcher in today's landscape, but Ramos fits the bill. His contact and hard-hit rates are both well above average -- not for a catcher, but for all batters. A high ground ball rate caps power, but because he hits the ball hard, he gets more hits on the ground than most players so slow afoot. Plus, when he does put it in the air, his HR/FB mark is consistently high. Durability is becoming an issue, as Ramos missed a month last season with a sore hamstring while also dealing with hand injuries on a couple of occasions. The veteran backstop's defense and game-calling remain solid, though. Ramos is the perfect compromise between paying market price for the elite receivers and waiting until the late game at the position.

After posting a career year in 2016, Seager declined significantly each of the past two campaigns. Last season was, by far, the worst in his eight-year career, as he set a personal high in strikeout rate and a low in walk rate. Unfortunately, Seager was also held back by a low .251 BABIP, exacerbating the slide in plate skills. The silver lining is the underlying metrics pointed to a higher hit rate, so there's positive regression in store. Whether Seager can recapture his previous plate skills is unclear, though at 31 years old, it's hard to envision him just losing it. Another plus is Seager's solid defense, which keeps him on the field. Speaking of which, Seager also has volume on his side, averaging 154 games and 663 plate appearances since 2012. Expect a modest rebound, tempered by a weaker supporting cast than previous seasons.

Injuries have obviously played a huge part, but the Nationals were expecting more when they acquired Eaton a couple of years ago. The concern now, even if Eaton is healthy, revolves around platoon splits, as Eaton has struggled mightily against southpaws since moving to the Senior circuit. By the book, he may not own these splits, but management may still decide to drop him into a platoon, especially since Michael A. Taylor has proved capable against left-handers. Additionally, there's also a chance Eaton hits lower in the order if Victor Robles demonstrates he's ready to join Trea Turner at the top. Eaton's contact and plate discipline provide a solid floor, albeit with limited power. Swiping nine bags in 10 tries shows Eaton can still contribute in that category. However, his playing-time concerns may make him better suited for daily leagues so you know for sure if he is in the lineup.

Hamstring and knee injuries ruined Sano's 2018, and his performance when healthy was so beneath expectations that at one point he was demoted to Class A ball -- granted to give him more access to the team's spring training facility rather than belonging there on merit -- for what was an eventual six-week stint in the minors. While he possesses power that can rival most anyone in baseball, with 84 home runs, .233 isolated power, a 15.5 percent Statcast "Barrel" per batted ball and 48.0 percent hard-contact rate in parts of four big-league seasons, his penchant for strikeouts puts him at massive risk for slumps and a low batting average. Even in his best of the four big-league seasons, he finished only 193rd on the Player Rater and tied for 249th in fantasy points, in 2017, so he'd need to have an eye-opening spring in order to warrant more than a late-round pick in rotisserie leagues or more than an AL-only/deep-mixed look in points-based formats. Sano's defense has also come into question, which is another problem that could cap his 2019 potential, as the Minnesota Twins added Nelson Cruz at designated hitter and effectively need Sano to handle the third base duties.

Semien returned to his everyday playing ways in 2018, but now with four full seasons under his belt, that 2016 power surge is looking more and more like an outlier. The 14.7 percent HR/FB rate from that season is 5 percentage points higher than any other season to date for the shortstop, and the Statcast data does not indicate a likely change in 2019 unless there is a change in his swing. Semien's swing plane and hard contact remained constant the past two seasons with only a slight variance in his fly ball rates. His increased pull rate on batted balls should ensure defenses continue to overshift him and thus limit his ability to push his batting average up beyond the league average, where it has resided the past two seasons. Semien's value comes from mass production built around playing time, as he does not really excel in any one area.

Gurriel will turn 35 years old next season, which helps explain why his third season in the majors virtually matched his second, save for a precipitous drop in power. Gurriel whiffed and walked the same as 2017, his BABIP was nearly identical, but his ISO dropped 49 points. Driving the power outage was a drop in hard-hit rate and decreased production versus right-handed pitching. In 2017, Gurriel hit 15 of his 18 homers facing righties, compared to just six of 13 last season. Because Gurriel put the ball in play 89 percent of the time, he usually hit in the heart of a productive order, helping produce a lofty 85 RBIs in just 573 plate appearances. Gurriel's added third-base eligibility makes him a nice choice for a late corner infielder, able to bounce between first and third and maximize lineup strength.

Nimmo excelled in a part-timer's role in the early stages of 2018, quickly graduating into an everyday role in which he batted .264/.374/.507 over an 80-game midsummer period and filled all five primary rotisserie categories with an impressive 11.1 percent walk rate (especially appealing in points-based leagues). A bruised left index finger suffered when he was hit by a pitch in mid-August cost him a disabled list stint, though, and he never really recaptured the same magic following his return. Nimmo's elite strike-zone judgment both elevates his statistical floor as well as makes him an interesting upside play in the stolen base category, as he's a legitimate five-category contributor even if he's not necessarily a star. He's one of the smarter fourth/fifth outfielders you could pick, and in those aforementioned points leagues, he could be a more significant contributor.

A power breakout was expected from Smoak long before 2017, as he was consistently among the leaders in fly ball distance, a strong indicator for home runs. As such, 2017 wasn't a huge surprise, though the extent of the spike was far greater than expected. Smart money was on regression, with the landing spot unclear. Smoak's fly ball rate has always been high, so it was a matter of maintaining a high HR/FB and contact rate. Both elements fell last season, resulting in a significant drop in power. Chances are, one or both will rebound this season, pushing Smoak's homers back around the 30 mark. Contact is still an issue, so his batting average is likely going to be a detriment. A high walk rate elevates Smoak's rank in OBP and points formats, though.

One of the fastest players in baseball, Hamilton's stolen base total unexpectedly plummeted last season. He hit noticeably more balls in the air -- his Statcast launch angle soared from 8.3 to 14.3 degrees, among the largest jumps in the game -- and for the first time in his six major league seasons he got green lights less than 30 percent of the time (25.0 percent in 2018). Now in Kansas City, Hamilton can only hope that the Royals afford him more freedom on the base paths, something that seems likely considering manager Ned Yost's recent tendencies, and he should resume his ground ball-oriented approach to hitting considering how poor Kauffman Stadium is for power. There's a lot of rebound potential in this move, especially if the Royals slot Hamilton atop the lineup in an attempt to maximize his stolen bases, something that might boost his runs scored total as well. He's a one-category performer far more valuable in rotisserie than points-based leagues -- Hamilton is barely even draft-worthy in mixed leagues in the latter -- but if you're seeking steals in the middle rounds, he's a worthy gamble.

Arguably the game's best defensive player, and a shortstop at that, Simmons is assured a maximum of playing time in which to generate counting numbers. But he's no slouch with the bat: He had the majors' highest contact rate last season (92.1 percent), has a longstanding reputation for elite numbers in that category, and couples that with a hint of pop and smarts on the base paths. Simmons range of outcomes is quite narrow, and that's not a bad thing, as he was a borderline top-100 player and top-10 fantasy shortstop last season, with slightly greater appeal in points-based than rotisserie leagues due to his contact.

Dickerson began 2018 by surprisingly being designated for assignment by the Rays, and he was dealt to the Pirates shortly thereafter. Dickerson went on to have a productive season in his return to the National League, but one in which he saw his power numbers take a step back from what he had done the previous two seasons in Tampa Bay. Dickerson ended up hitting a surprising .300 for the first time away from Coors Field, and did so by dramatically reducing his strikeout rate to 15.0 percent last season. An improved approach that focused on contact over power saw him reduce his swinging strike rate by nearly 4 full percentage points and push his overall contact rate up from 74 percent to 80 percent. This kind of metamorphosis one year away from free agency is odd, but Dickerson hitting for average rather than power seems to be the new reality.

Bauers showed good power initially after his promotion to the Tampa Bay Rays, posting a .487 slugging percentage and .251 isolated power in his first 52 games. But he slumped badly thereafter, hitting .154/.268/.243 with a 29.5 percent strikeout rate in his next 44. Predictably, pitchers adapted and challenged him with breaking balls, which will require an adjustment on his part in order to fully unlock his potential. The Cleveland Indians took a chance by trading for him during the winter, perhaps noticing that he's a pull-power hitter who should be much better suited for Progressive Field than Tropicana Field. Bauers is worth a look in the late rounds of mixed leagues, but he might be best suited for daily leagues, where you can pick and choose his matchups, preferably avoiding games against left-handed pitchers and using those in hitter-friendly parks.

Summoned for good by the Tampa Bay Rays in mid-June, Adames held his own as a rookie, his .278/.348/.406 rates in 85 games remarkably close to the .280/.358/.414 numbers he had in 194 Triple-A games between 2017-18. Still, his 67 percent contact and 52 percent ground-ball rates in the majors don't bode well for his chances of repeating the performance, meaning that further adjustments should be expected. Adames does have the power/speed combination that should make him a potential top-10 fantasy shortstop in a couple of years, but for now he's better suited for middle infielder status in mixed leagues.

Herrera once had the makings of a top-of-the-order table-setter with speed. However, in recent seasons, his walk and stolen base success rates have dropped considerably. Herrera used to spray the ball to all fields, but over the past two seasons, his pull rate has increased. The result is that he's hitting just .192 when defensed with a shift in 31 percent of his plate appearances, compared to .318 in the other 69 percent of his trips to the dish. Another issue is that Herrera's defense in center was a detriment. With the Phillies in go-for-it mode, Herrera will need to find a way to revert to 2016 form, lest he fall in jeopardy of losing playing time. He's still a fantasy asset ? just don't get caught in the "best outfielder on the board" trap, chasing a player with a shaky floor.

Cron is a statuesque target at first with limited mobility, but it appears he will start there for the Twins in 2019 thanks to the team's addition of fellow power bat Nelson Cruz. Cron is coming off a career year in which he took advantage of consistent playing time not afforded him by Anaheim, and parlayed it into a 30-homer season while also setting career highs in runs and runs driven in. Cron had the best year of his career against lefties, hitting 47 points higher than any other season against southpaws, but saw his average against righties drop to a career-worst .231 with the extra playing time. Hitting with runners in scoring position is more about opportunity than skill, but it was one area that was not part of the breakout season, as Cron hit .196/.284/.377 and struck out 27 percent of the time in those situations.

Alfaro is a cannon-armed backstop, his defensive skill likely to fuel a healthy amount of playing time in this, his second full big-league season. That's good, because he's going to need it in order to make his counting numbers register in fantasy, as he brings above-average power but has some of the worst plate discipline in baseball. Last season, Alfaro averaged one walk per 7.7 strikeouts, the second-worst rate among players with at least 350 plate appearances. That makes him more of a liability in points-based leagues, where he's only a fringe contender for top-12 catcher status because of the possibility of significant playing time. In rotisserie, Alfaro's chances at a breakthrough 20-homer campaign could give him an outside chance at top-10 status. He should be on your "wait until the end" draft targets in standard leagues, but more of a high-end No. 2 catcher everywhere else.

The book on Bell as a prospect was a line-drive, gap hitter, so his 2017 power spike was considered somewhat questionable. The main reason was Bell's hard-hit and fly ball rates didn't portend such a lofty power surge, so the resultant 19.1 HR/FB mark was due to regress. Sure enough, last season, Bell maintained similar underlying power metrics, yet posted a 9.2 HR/FB. The only difference from the previous season was the switch-hitter pulled the ball more in 2017, but that doesn't explain the entire difference, if any. Bell's above-average plate skills drive a solid floor, especially in OBP and points leagues. After that, his fantasy potential will be defined by his ability to produce runs, which is obviously team-dependent. The Pirates finished in the lower half in scoring last season and probably will again, dampening Bell's run and RBI potential.

Escobar picked the right time to have a career year and capitalized by signing a three-year deal to return to the Diamondbacks in lieu of testing the free-agent market. A utility infielder throughout his career, Escobar began the campaign as the Twins' regular shortstop with Jorge Polanco suspended. He shifted to the hot corner when Polanco returned, maintaining full-time status. Arizona acquired Escobar in late July, ostensibly as a utility man. However, Jake Lamb hurt his shoulder, simultaneous with the trade, so Escobar took over for the rest of the season. Aside from setting personal highs in games and plate appearances, Escobar's 117 wRC+ was his best ever, fueled by posting an above-average hard-hit rate for the first time. Escobar is earmarked to be the Opening Day third baseman, though he retains shortstop eligibility. Solid plate skills give Escobar a bankable floor, with his dual eligibility a useful bonus.

There's little doubt that Jimenez is big-league-ready, after he slashed .355/.399/.597 with 12 home runs and an 85.8 percent contact rate in 55 games for Triple-A Charlotte last summer. The question is now whether the Chicago White Sox want to start his service-time clock, though it's possible they will if they believe they're on the road to contention. Jimenez, Keith Law's No. 5 overall prospect, brings a polished combination of batting average and raw power, one of the few players as likely to bat .300 as hit 30-plus homers (though both of those thresholds might come closer to his prime than as a rookie). He's among the top candidates for Rookie of the Year honors, should be regarded as a top-40 fantasy outfielder, even if he spends the first few weeks of the season in the minors, and in fact has slightly greater value in points-based than rotisserie leagues thanks to his reputation for good contact.

DeJong burst onto the scene in 2017 with a 25-homer showing over 443 plate appearances, flashing the pop necessary to project as a 30-plus-homer bat with a full season's worth of playing time. He took a small step back in the power department last season, losing nearly 100 points from his slugging percentage (.433) despite improved walk and strikeout rates. A broken hand in May might have been the primary culprit for his reduced power output, as he hit eight homers in 171 plate appearances (.473 SLG) before suffering the injury in mid-May. The addition of Paul Goldschmidt provides a big boost to the St. Louis lineup, and if Goldschmidt bats second in the order, DeJong would be the favorite to open the season in the coveted third spot. He should have plenty of run and RBI chances if he does bat third, which would be good enough to offset his batting average risk and minimal contributions as a base stealer.

Coming off a breakthrough second half of 2017, during which time he batted .300/.347/.546 with 11 home runs and 13 stolen bases in 57 games, Buxton struggled through a nightmarish 2018 on multiple levels. He batted just .156 and struck out in 29.8 percent of his trips to the plate in the season's first two months, landed on the disabled list due to migraines, broke his toe in his first minor league rehabilitation game, and was unable to fully recover from the latter until midsummer. By that point, the Minnesota Twins decided to keep him at Triple-A Rochester in order to push back his free agency by a year, though his .274/.333/.459 triple-slash rates in 35 games for them hardly demanded a promotion back to the big club. Buxton should be in the lead for the center field job this spring, in large part because of his elite defense, and he still has the exceptional speed along with a hint of pop that make him an intriguing speculative rotisserie pick. So long as he looks healthy in March, he's worthy of a mid-to-late round pick, though his mediocre plate discipline makes him a bit less valuable than that in points leagues.

There was a fair amount of hype surrounding Polanco heading into the 2018 season before he was hit with an 80-game PED suspension. The ironic part about the story is that his final 2018 triple-slash line (.288/.345/.427) was better than what he did in 2017 (.256/.313/.410). If we lazily doubled his 2018 numbers, he would have equaled or exceeded his counting numbers from the 2017 seasons. Dating back to August 1, 2017, Polanco has been 25 percent better than the league average offensively and has a .299/.358/.478 line over nearly 570 plate appearances. There is an excellent chance Polanco hits leadoff in 2019 for a retooled Minnesota lineup that added a lot of pop this offseason. Polanco has the on-base chops to make that work and could see a significant spike in his runs scored this season.

Jones closed out his six-year, $85.5 million deal with the Orioles last season, remaining in Baltimore in a completely lost season and topping 600 plate appearances for the eighth time in the last nine campaigns. Though he's never been a patient hitter (career 4.4 percent walk rate), Jones continued to put the ball in play frequently, posting a 15.2 percent strikeout rate and hitting .281. But his power slipped, as he failed to hit 20 homers for the first time since 2010. Only two outfielders graded out as worse defenders based on Statcast's Outs Above Average formula in 2018, and a full-time move to a corner-outfield spot will almost certainly come in 2019. Now 33 years old, he may be forced to take a short-term deal or accept a part-time role to land with a contender. His best path to a heavy volume of playing time will come from a rebuilding club seeking a steady veteran presence in the clubhouse.

Keith Law's No. 9 overall prospect entering 2018 and No. 6 entering 2019, Senzel is a man without an apparent position, at least as far as the Cincinnati Reds' current roster is concerned. A natural third baseman who also played second base in college, Senzel dabbled at shortstop early last season, though the team appears set at all three of those positions. He might factor into the team's outfield picture, though there's little doubt that his bat could help the big club right now, considering he batted .310/.378/.509 in 44 games for Triple-A Louisville in 2018, before a broken right index finger prematurely ended his season. Senzel also required an October surgery to remove bone spurs from his left elbow, so he'll bear watching during spring training, and might begin the year in the minors in order to first work his way back to full strength. He'll almost assuredly make his debut for the Reds during 2019, though, and could be a borderline top-10 fantasy third baseman from that point forward, with his skill set slightly more attractive in points-based than rotisserie leagues. Stash him even in mixed leagues, and consider him a top dynasty/keeper league prospect.

It was a typical season for Choo, albeit with less run production than usual. The Rangers scored 62 fewer runs than they did in 2017, but the real culprit was Choo posting a .225 average with runners in scoring position. He didn't become "unclutch"; he was a victim of poor timing, clustering hits without ducks on the pond. Of some concern are exaggerated splits, as Choo slashed .293/.405/.506 over the first half, in contrast to .217/.329/.316 during the second half. Perhaps it was due to the hotter-than-normal Texas heat wearing down the 36-year-old veteran. Choo is assured of playing nearly every day when healthy, which he was the past two seasons. At some point, Father Time catches up to everyone, but there's no indication Choo is in decline. There's no upside, but if you need outfield stability, Choo can provide it.

There is minimal discernible difference between Mancini's underlying metrics the past two seasons. Be it Statcast data, plate skills or batted ball distribution, they're all remarkably similar. Yet, in 2017 Mancini recorded a .352 BABIP, which plummeted to .285 last season. The lower batting average, along with the weak Orioles offense, dropped Mancini's RBI to 58, extremely low for a power hitter appearing in 156 games. Curiously, Mancini, a righty swinger, has handled right-handed pitchers much better than southpaws, though it's too early in his career to definitively label him a reverse-splits hitter. Defensively, Mancini is a poor outfielder, and he really should be moved back to first base. Baltimore is still in rebuild mode, so Mancini will be given another season to develop. Look for a rebound in batting average but continued middling production in a porous lineup.

Zunino is a hitter who brings big power but poor contact, therefore walking a fine line between being fantasy-relevant and a liability for our purposes based upon how lucky he is on batted balls and how streaky he's being with his poor contact. His 45 home runs the past two seasons combined are fourth-best among catchers, and he has gotten there with the position's highest fly-ball rate (38.2 percent) and sixth-highest hard contact rate (39.1 percent). Zunino's strikeout rate, though, is also a position-worst 36.9 percent. He moved to one of the most pitching-friendly environments in baseball this winter in Tampa Bay's Tropicana Field, so home runs might be slightly tougher to come by, too. Zunino should do enough to warrant top-10 catcher status due to the position's lack of depth, but he's one of the more risk/reward backstops and is more of a liability in points-based scoring.

The book on Gurriel was that he was "empty" batting average. However, last season he displayed some latent pop, giving hope that there's more in his fantasy arsenal to come. As encouraging as his 2018 numbers were, proceed with caution. The underlying metrics don't fully portend a sustained power breakout. Gurriel's hard-hit rate and average exit velocity support his 17.5 HR/FB, but a low average launch angle generates only a 30-percent fly ball rate. Plus, Gurriel has yet to establish a contact rate baseline -- though there are strong indications it will be above-average, albeit with few walks in the mix. Volume is what saves Gurriel, as the keystone in Toronto appears to have his name on it. Plus, he could occupy a spot near the top of the Torontobatting order. There's risk, but Gurriel's ability to put the ball in play should at least offer a batting-average floor, with the hope of some production in the power categories.

Taylor has continued his conversion from a line-drive hitter to one who tries to drive the ball over the fence. He raised his average launch angle yet again in 2018 to the point it is now nearly double where it was in 2016. His average exit velocity has remained the same, but even an average-distance increase and more plate appearances didn't allow him to replicate his 2017 homer total. A decline of five percentage points in his strikeout rate was a contributing factor to his 34-point drop in batting average from 2017, but the larger factor was his output against southpaws. Taylor hit .297 against lefties in 2017 as he broke out, but he hit just .232 last season in 214 plate appearances, seeing his BABIP against them drop nearly 120 points. He begins this season eligible at both shortstop and outfield, and he should pick up one or two positions during the season.

Looking for stability at the hot corner, the Giants acquired Longoria from the Rays last winter. It took a fluke hit by pitch, but the durable veteran visited the disabled list for the first time since 2012 after missing just a dozen games in that span. In mid-June, Longoria was hit on the left hand, requiring surgery to mend the fracture. During his rehab stint, he was drilled on the triceps, delaying his return until late July. AT&T Park should have helped Longoria's average while costing him some power. The opposite occurred, though, as his ISO inched up while his batting average slid to .244, matching his 2011 mark for a personal low. Longoria's plate skills also dipped, as his 0.22 BB/K was the poorest of his career. Finally, his once-stellar defense continued to decline. Longoria will continue to play every day, but mixed leaguers should still look elsewhere for a more productive option.

Summoned by the Pittsburgh Pirates in mid-May to fill in for the injured Starling Marte, Meadows held his own over 49 games for their big club, his .292/.327/.468 triple-slash rates looking somewhat similar to the .264/.322/.446 numbers he had over parts of three seasons in Triple-A ball. Later traded to the Tampa Bay Rays in the Chris Archer deal, Meadows got only a 10 game cup of coffee for his new team, though they certainly see a bright future ahead and should clear a regular outfield role for him in the early stages of the year -- his service time situation probably ultimately dictating his promotion date. He brings an appealing combination of power and speed, a 15/20 type who is capable enough with the bat to contribute across the board in rotisserie. Meadows is well worth a speculative pick to round out your mixed-league outfield, though it's worth keeping an eye on his role as the spring progresses.

The New York Yankees acquired Voit from the first base-rich St. Louis Cardinals in late July, and due to Greg Bird's struggles with injuries and strikeouts, granted him a chance to play regularly down the stretch. What a good idea it was: He started 31 of the Yankees' final 36 games, batting .351/.426/.763 with 14 home runs and 31 RBIs. It was the best possible outcome he could've expected, and put him in the lead for starting first base duties entering spring training, which keeps him on the AL-only and deep-mixed radar. Voit's numbers are sure to regress, as he cannot possibly repeat a .365 BABIP or 22.7 home run/fly ball percentage, though he's capable enough making contact and generates enough fly balls to make use of Yankee Stadium's cozy confines. So long as he can hold onto the job, he should put forth numbers worthy of the mixed league corner infield tier.

Bradley is an elite defender, and it is that defense that kept him in the major leagues all season. His triple-slash line on Fathers Day sat at .184/.280/.301, which is the type of line that gets 99.9 percent of hitters demoted to Triple-A to work on things. The Red Sox valued his glove enough to keep him up and let him work through things, and they were rewarded when he hit .272/.341/.481 the rest of the season with nine home runs and 10 steals. The overall numbers are still a step back from the expectations his 2016 season set, but StatCast shows he left a lot of production on the table, as his expected wOBA trailed his actual OBP by 30 points. The indicators show a recent increase in exit velocity and more loft on his batted balls, making a 20/20 season with plenty of runs possible in 2019.

Alonso maintained most of the power gains he showed in 2017, posting a fly ball rate above 40 percent and swatting 23 homers while driving in a career-high 83 runs for Cleveland as the team's primary first baseman. For the second straight season, his added pop came at the expense of more whiffs -- he fanned more than 20 percent of the time -- but he continues to show a patient eye at the plate (8.9 percent walk rate). A flurry of offseason moves by the Indians included a trade that sent Alonso to the White Sox, where he's now positioned to split his playing time between first base and the DH spot, rotating with Jose Abreu. The new approach appears to be here to stay, and he should play enough to hit 20 homers again, with the chance to be one of the team's top run producers near the heart of the order.

Beggars cannot be choosers when it comes to rostering catchers in fantasy baseball, but even beggars should think twice about rostering Hedges. His fly ball approach to hitting can net you 15 homers or so, but his approach sells out consistent contact and he has more average and on-base percentage downside in his game than upside. StatCast data tells us Hedges significantly overperformed the quality of his contact, as his expected batting average was nearly 20 points below his actual mark and he outperformed his expected slugging by nearly 70 points. Hedges has become a pull-heavy fly ball hitter, which leads to him doing better against righties than lefties, but the hitting profile is fraught with risks. His defense keeps him in the lineup more days than not, but plan on Hedges taking a step back, and not one forward.

Alonso has developed into one of the more powerful prospects in baseball, having led all minor leaguers with 36 home runs last season, then tying for the Arizona Fall League lead with an additional six. That put him on the radar as a possible option for the New York Mets at first base this season, if not on Opening Day than surely by midseason. Alonso would probably be the favorite to pace rookies in homers in 2019 if he's in the majors for long enough, but there are adjustment-related concerns, in that he managed those lofty totals in extremely hitting-friendly environments, has become a bit of a pull-conscious slugger and has shifted from what was a more contact-oriented approach during his college days. He'd need to open some eyes during spring training to be more than a speculative mixed-league pick, and even then, he might be a risky one in points-based leagues due to the strikeouts.

A .323/.400/.484 minor league triple-slash line across three competitive levels in 2017 put Jansen on the top-prospect map, and he continued to show offensive growth at Triple-A Buffalo to begin last season, batting .275/.390/.473 with 12 home runs in 88 games to earn a promotion to the Toronto Blue Jays in mid-August. He held his own, flashing promising plate-discipline skills and getting good lift on the ball, though his modest hard-contact rate hinted he hasn't fully adapted to the tougher competition. The Blue Jays nevertheless traded Russell Martin during the winter to pave the way for Jansen to start in 2019, and he's one of the higher-floor players with a good promise of playing time at his position. Jansen is an ideal No. 2 catcher for leagues that require one, but he's probably not yet ready to make a push to be one of his position's best.

Polanco struggled out of the gate last season, hitting the ball in the air more often but at the expense of making consistently good contact. He was essentially a league-average hitter for the first two months, but things clicked in June as he started to do a lot of damage when he connected, hitting 15 homers in 318 plate appearances from June 1 on while posting a .281/.354/.547 line during that span. He was also more active on the basepaths during the final four months, finishing 12-of-14 as a base stealer. The final results included a career-high walk rate (11.4 percent), OBP (.340), slugging percentage (.499) and home run total (23), with a fly ball rate that was 10 percentage points higher than his career 38.0 percent mark. Unfortunately, his season came to a premature end when he dislocated his shoulder in early September. The surgery required the repair of torn cartilage in his labrum and his timetable for a return could extend into May or June, depending on how he progresses through his rehab work.

A free agent at the beginning of spring training (still!), Gonzalez should still carry a lot of appeal to both real-life and fantasy teams thanks to his versatility. He's first base, second base, shortstop and outfield eligible in ESPN leagues, which could be a big help with his signing team because of his ability to handle a multitude of roles. Still, Gonzalez regressed significantly as a hitter last season, following up his .299/.363/.485 second-half triple slash rates from the second half of 2017, which showed a downturn from his start of that year as is, with .247/.324/.409 rates in 2018. There's value in a player like this, a swiss-army-knife type who logs enough playing time to make his counting numbers register while serving a handy plug-in all around a mixed league roster, though it's more so in the mid-to-late rounds than sooner in your draft.

Marte, more of a baserunning/defense prospect at the time of his 2015 big-league debut, finally began to show some signs of growth with the bat when given regular playing time by the Arizona Diamondbacks last season. While he inexplicably stopped running, attempting only seven stolen bases in 153 games, he posted career bests in terms of contact rate (84.8 percent), slugging percentage (.437), isolated power (.177) and hard-contact rate (36.5 percent of his balls in play). Marte would need to improve his hitting from the left side of the plate to take another significant step forward, as he slashed just .224/.300/.352 against them in 2018, but he's likely to get the chance to with regular at-bats on a rebuilding Diamondbacks team. Best yet: He's expected to shift to center field this season, potentially giving him in-season eligibility there to add to his second base/shortstop dual eligibility already.

Braun sat with just a .235 batting average at the All-Star break last season, but hidden in that number was a serious run of bad luck. Braun's fortunes changed after the break, and he hit .281 while posting an .879 OPS the rest of the regular season. Braun's days of being an everyday player are in the past, but fewer games are seemingly a benefit in his case, as it keeps him fresher and more productive when he is on the field. He isn't the fantasy anchor he used to be, but he's certainly more than roster filler still. Braun turned 35 during the winter, so it's unlikely he will play more than the 125 games he played in 2018 in what was a relatively healthy season. However, he's still going to get at-bats when he's not injured, and will hit in the top portion of the order when he plays. With Christian Yelich and Lorenzo Cain finishing third and fourth, respectively, in the NL in OBP last season, Braun will have plenty opportunities to knock in runs, particularly if his offseason attempt to increase his launch angle pays off.
